FedMeS: Personalized Federated Continual Learning Leveraging Local Memory

Jin Xie1, Chenqing Zhu1, and Songze Li2

1The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (Guangzhou)

2Southeast University

††footnotetext:
 Regular Paper

Abstract  We focus on the problem of Personalized Federated Continual Learning (PFCL): a group of distributed clients, each with a sequence of local tasks on arbitrary data distributions, collaborate through a central server to train a personalized model at each client, with the model expected to achieve good performance on all local tasks. We propose a novel PFCL framework called Federated Memory Strengthening (FedMeS) to address the challenges of client drift and catastrophic forgetting. In FedMeS, each client stores samples from previous tasks using a small amount of local memory, and leverages this information to both 1) calibrate gradient updates in training process; and 2) perform KNN-based Gaussian inference to facilitate personalization. FedMeS is designed to be task-oblivious, such that the same inference process is applied to samples from all tasks to achieve good performance. FedMeS is analyzed theoretically and evaluated experimentally. It is shown to outperform all baselines in average accuracy and forgetting rate, over various combinations of datasets, task distributions, and client numbers.

Keywords  Federated Learning, Continual Learning, Personalization, Memory

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) [1] is an emerging distributed learning framework that allows for collaborative training of a model across multiple clients while keeping their raw data locally stored. A typical FL process involves local training on each client and global model aggregation on a cloud server, with only model updates or gradients being shared between clients and the server.

Data collected from different clients in an FL system often have drastically different distributions. As seen in Figure Fig. 1(a), this can lead to model parameter divergence and client drift [2], causing potentially poor performance for certain clients. The conventional way of training a single model is insufficient to fit all the non-IID data, and a personalized model needs to be trained for each participating client [3, 4], which is known as personalized FL.

Another key characteristic in real-world FL systems is that clients are continuously collecting new data (new task) which may exhibit different distributions from previous local data (tasks). Hence, it would be preferable to train a local model that is able to achieve consistently good performance in all local tasks. In an FL system, the problem is solved by federated continual learning (FCL) [5, 6, 7]. The phenomenon of a model failing to perform well on previously trained tasks is called catastrophic forgetting [8], which is illustrated in Fig. 1(b).

In practical FL systems, the data and task heterogeneity often exist both across clients and over time on a single client. For instance, as shown in Fig. 1(c), in a IIoT scenario, multiple factories manufacturing different products would like to use FL for training defect detection models collaboratively. Other than the difference between the types of products, each factory may experience change of tasks over time due to e.g., change of recipe and upgrade of the production line. Aiming to address the challenges of client drift and catastrophic forgetting simultaneously, in the paper we focus on the personalized federated continual learning (PFCL) problem. In a PFCL system, each client observes a stream of arbitrarily different tasks, and would like to collaborate through the server to train a personalized model, which performs well on both previous and current local tasks.

There have been prior attempts at tackling the FCL problem, like FedWeIT [7], where task-generic and task-specific knowledge are shared across clients to decompose the model parameters. However, as demonstrated in [2], FedWeIT struggles to handle the issue of client drift caused by data heterogeneity and has poor scalability as the number of tasks increases.

In this paper, we propose a novel PFCL framework called Federated Memory Strengthening (FedMeS). FedMeS utilizes small amount of local memory at each client to store information about previous tasks, and leverage this memory to assist both the training and inference processes. During training process, the gradients are constantly calibrated against the data samples from previous tasks to avoid catastrophic forgetting. A newly designed regularization term scaled by a loss-based parameter is used to facilitate the training of personalized models, using information from the global model. In the inference process, FedMeS further leverages the memory information to perform KNN-based Gaussian inference, further strengthening the model’s personalization capability. Moreover, FedMeS exhibits a major advantage of being task-oblivious, meaning that the inference processes for test samples from all tasks are identical, and all are expected to achieve high performance.

We theoretically characterize the convergence of FedMeS, and empirically evaluate its performance over various dataset combinations, task constructions, task distributions, and client numbers. Over all experiments, FedMeS uniformly outperforms all baselines in terms of accuracy metrics and forgetting rate. Performance of FedMeS under different memory sizes and its execution times are also experimentally investigated.

2 Related Work

Personalized Federated Learning. A simple idea is by deploying a global model and fine tuning parameters through gradient descent on local clients [9, 10, 11]. Meta-learning based FL methods realize model personalization through hyperparameters [12]. PerKNN [13] is a special case, where embeddings of training samples are stored for local memorization for KNN-based Gaussian inference. The mainstream design is to interpolate a global model and one local model per client, and the task-specific models are learned both globally and locally [14, 15]. Below are some methods adopting this design. Regularization terms on proximal models help construct personalized information [16, 17]. Sometimes an initialized model or regularizer-based learnable bases are constructed for each client [3]. In other cases, multiple global models are trained at the server, and task-specific regularization terms force similar tasks to be close, making the training on heterogeneous clients more accurate [18, 19].

Continual Learning. Memory replay methods are widely used in continual learning (CL) to maintain prediction accuracies of past tasks. Generally speaking, a memory buffer is used to store previous data which are replayed while learning a new task to alleviate forgetting [20, 21]. Experience replay (ER) jointly optimizes the network parameters by interleaving the previous task exemplars with current task data [22, 23]. An alternative solution is by constrained optimization. GEM [24] and A-GEM [25] leverage episodic memory to compute previous task gradients to constrain the current update step. Pesudo Rehearsal [26] is used in early works with shallow neural networks. Generative-based methods [27] synthesize previous data produced by generative models and replay the synthesized data. Besides replay methods, regularization-based methods [28, 29] and parameter isolation methods [30] have also been proposed for CL.

Although a lot of work has been done in CL, just a few works have tried to use CL in a federated setting. FedWeIT [7] is a typical one, where task-generic and task-specific knowledge are shared across clients to decompose the model parameters. However, as demonstrated in [2], FedWeIT struggles to handle the issue of client drift caused by data heterogeneity and does not address the scalability of tasks. Other methods, like LFedCon2 [31], use traditional classifiers instead of DNN and propose an algorithm dealing with a concept drift based on ensemble retraining. FLwF and FLwF-2T [32] use a distillation-based approach dealing with catastrophic forgetting in FL scenario and focus on the class-incremental learning scenario.

3 Problem Definition

We consider an FL system that consists of n𝑛n clients and a central server. Over time, each client k𝑘k (k=1,…,n𝑘1…𝑛k=1,\ldots,n) continually collects private datasets from a sequence of T𝑇T machine learning tasks. For each task t𝑡t (t=1,…,T𝑡1…𝑇t=1,\ldots,T), the corresponding dataset at client k𝑘k is denoted as 𝒟ktsuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑡\mathcal{D}_{k}^{t}. We focus on a general non-IID case, where 𝒟ktsuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑡\mathcal{D}_{k}^{t} is drawn from some probability distribution 𝒫ktsuperscriptsubscript𝒫𝑘𝑡{\cal P}_{k}^{t}, and no particular relationships for 𝒫ktsuperscriptsubscript𝒫𝑘𝑡{\cal P}_{k}^{t} across k𝑘k and t𝑡t are assumed.

The conventional FL problem corresponds to a single-task scenario. For a particular task t𝑡t, the following objective function is optimized over the global model 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}:

min𝐰⁡𝒢​(F1​(𝐰;𝒟1t),…,Fn​(𝐰;𝒟nt))subscript𝐰𝒢subscript𝐹1𝐰superscriptsubscript𝒟1𝑡…subscript𝐹𝑛𝐰superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑛𝑡\min_{\mathbf{w}}\mathcal{G}(F_{1}(\mathbf{w};\mathcal{D}_{1}^{t}),\ldots,F_{n}(\mathbf{w};\mathcal{D}_{n}^{t})) (1)

where Fk​(⋅)subscript𝐹𝑘⋅F_{k}(\cdot) is a local objective for client k𝑘k and 𝒢​(⋅)𝒢⋅\mathcal{G}(\cdot) is some aggregation function.

In the general case of evolving tasks, each client intends to obtain a personalized model which maintains good performance on all its previous tasks. Motivated by this need, we incorporate the concept of continual learning and into a personalized FL framework, and formally define the personalized federated continual learning (PFCL) problem below. Specifically, for each task t𝑡t, the personalized model wktsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡w_{k}^{t} for each client k𝑘k is obtained through

minwktsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡\displaystyle\min_{w_{k}^{t}} Gk​(wkt;𝐰∗)=ℒ​(wkt;𝒟kt)+λ2​‖wkt−𝐰∗‖2,subscript𝐺𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscript𝐰ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑡𝜆2superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscript𝐰2\displaystyle{G}_{k}(w_{k}^{t};\mathbf{w^{*}})=\mathcal{L}\left(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{D}_{k}^{t}\right)+\frac{\lambda}{2}\left\|w_{k}^{t}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\right\|^{2}, (2)
s.t. 𝐰∗∈arg⁡min𝐰​𝒢​(ℒ​(𝐰;𝒟1t),…,ℒ​(𝐰;𝒟nt)),superscript𝐰𝐰𝒢ℒ𝐰superscriptsubscript𝒟1𝑡…ℒ𝐰superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑛𝑡\displaystyle\mathbf{w^{*}}\in\underset{\mathbf{w}}{\arg\min}\ \mathcal{G}\left(\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w};\mathcal{D}_{1}^{t}),...,\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w};\mathcal{D}_{n}^{t})\right),
ℒ​(wkt;𝐃kt−1)≤ℒ​(wkt−1;𝐃kt−1).ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐃𝑘𝑡1ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝐃𝑘𝑡1\displaystyle\mathcal{L}\left(w_{k}^{t};\mathbf{D}_{k}^{t-1}\right)\leq\mathcal{L}\left(w_{k}^{t-1};\mathbf{D}_{k}^{t-1}\right).

Here 𝐃kt−1=(𝒟k1,…,𝒟kt−1)superscriptsubscript𝐃𝑘𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘1…superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑡1\mathbf{D}_{k}^{t-1}=({\cal D}_{k}^{1},\ldots,{\cal D}_{k}^{t-1}), and ℒ​(w;𝐃)ℒ𝑤𝐃\mathcal{L}(w;\mathbf{D}) is the empirical loss of w𝑤w on dataset 𝐃𝐃\mathbf{D}. The last constraint ensures that the new model obtained from task t𝑡t has a lower loss than the old model over previous datasets, effectively alleviating the forgetting of previous tasks.

4 The Proposed FedMeS Framework

We propose an algorithm, Federated Memory Strengthening (FedMeS), to solve the PFCL problem defined in (2). The key idea of FedMeS is to design local memory data samples from previous tasks, and flexibly use them in both training and inference processes. In training process, the local memory is used for gradient correction to avoid catastrophic forgetting; in inference process, a KNN algorithm based on the representations of local samples helps to improve the accuracy of the personalized model. The overall workflow of FedMeS is illustrated in Figure 2, and pseudocode is given in Algorithm 1.

4.1 Memory design

In FedMeS, we utilize a small amount of memory at each client to help meeting the constraint of ℒ​(wkt;𝐃kt−1)≤ℒ​(wkt−1;𝐃kt−1)ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐃𝑘𝑡1ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝐃𝑘𝑡1\mathcal{L}\left(w_{k}^{t};\mathbf{D}_{k}^{t-1}\right)\leq\mathcal{L}\left(w_{k}^{t-1};\mathbf{D}_{k}^{t-1}\right) in (2). Specifically, given a fixed memory size m𝑚m, each client k𝑘k constructs and stores a dataset ℳkt⊂⋃i=1t−1𝒟kisuperscriptsubscriptℳ𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑖\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t}\subset\bigcup_{i=1}^{t-1}\mathcal{D}_{k}^{i} with |ℳkt|≤msuperscriptsubscriptℳ𝑘𝑡𝑚|\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t}|\leq m, through sub-sampling data points from each of the previous datasets. For the initial task, ℳk1=∅superscriptsubscriptℳ𝑘1\mathcal{M}_{k}^{1}=\emptyset. After completing task t𝑡t, a small number of mtsuperscript𝑚𝑡m^{t} data points are randomly sampled from 𝒟ktsuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑡{\cal D}_{k}^{t}, and combined with ℳktsuperscriptsubscriptℳ𝑘𝑡\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t} to form ℳkt+1superscriptsubscriptℳ𝑘𝑡1\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t+1} for the next task t+1𝑡1t+1. The FIFO scheduling is adopted, such that when the memory is full, data points from older tasks are popped to make space for incoming tasks. By utilizing ℳktsuperscriptsubscriptℳ𝑘𝑡\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t} as a compact representation of 𝐃kt−1superscriptsubscript𝐃𝑘𝑡1\mathbf{D}_{k}^{t-1}, FedMeS aims to solve a PFCL problem, with the constraint ℒ​(wkt;𝐃kt−1)≤ℒ​(wkt−1;𝐃kt−1)ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐃𝑘𝑡1ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝐃𝑘𝑡1\mathcal{L}\left(w_{k}^{t};\mathbf{D}_{k}^{t-1}\right)\leq\mathcal{L}\left(w_{k}^{t-1};\mathbf{D}_{k}^{t-1}\right) in the (2) replaced by

ℒ​(wkt;ℳkt)≤ℒ​(wkt−1;ℳkt).ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscriptℳ𝑘𝑡ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡1superscriptsubscriptℳ𝑘𝑡\mathcal{L}\left(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t}\right)\leq\mathcal{L}\left(w_{k}^{t-1};\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t}\right). (3)

4.2 Training Process of FedMeS

The training of task t𝑡t (t=1,…,T𝑡1…𝑇t=1,\ldots,T) proceeds over multiple global iterations between the server and the clients. In each global iteration, the server broadcasts the global model 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} to the clients, waits for clients to upload personalized models wktsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡w_{k}^{t}, and aggregates them to update the global model 𝐰←1n​∑k=1nwkt←𝐰1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡\mathbf{w}\leftarrow\frac{1}{n}\sum_{k=1}^{n}w_{k}^{t}.

During local training process, each client k𝑘k runs multiple local iterations to update wktsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡w_{k}^{t}. In each local iteration, client k𝑘k starts with the global model 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} and perform SGD according to the objective in (2) to update wktsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡w_{k}^{t}. The model update for each mini-batch is different according to whether the condition (3) is satisfied. For a better compatibility with running SGD, we alternatively consider the following condition on the inner product of current gradients on current and previous tasks:

⟨∇ℒ​(wkt;𝒟kt),∇ℒ​(wkt;ℳkt)⟩≥0,∇ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑡∇ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscriptℳ𝑘𝑡0\left\langle\nabla\mathcal{L}\left(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{D}_{k}^{t}\right),\nabla\mathcal{L}\left(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t}\right)\right\rangle\geq 0, (4)

which was shown in [25] equivalent to the condition in (3).

When (4) is satisfied, it means that the updates on current task t𝑡t and previous tasks are roughly in the same direction, so the optimization on current task would not negatively impact the performance of past tasks. As a result, it is safe to update the model along the gradient of current task as follows, for some learning rate η1subscript𝜂1\eta_{1}:

wkt=wkt−η1​(∇ℒ​(wkt;𝒟kt)+λ​‖wkt−𝐰‖).superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡subscript𝜂1∇ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑡𝜆normsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡𝐰w_{k}^{t}=w_{k}^{t}-\eta_{1}\left(\nabla\mathcal{L}(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{D}_{k}^{t})+\lambda\|w_{k}^{t}-\mathbf{w}\|\right). (5)

When (4) does not hold, client k𝑘k first adjusts its local weights wktsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡w_{k}^{t} to avoid forgetting, through the following gradient correction step, for some learning rate η2subscript𝜂2\eta_{2}:

wkt=wkt−superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡limit-fromsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡\displaystyle w_{k}^{t}=w_{k}^{t}- η2(∇ℒ(wkt;𝒟kt)−\displaystyle\eta_{2}\bigg{(}\nabla\mathcal{L}(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{D}_{k}^{t})- (6)
∇ℒ​(wkt;𝒟kt)⊤​∇ℒ​(wkt;ℳkt)∇ℒ​(wkt;ℳkt)⊤​∇ℒ​(wkt;ℳkt)∇ℒ(wkt;ℳkt)).\displaystyle\frac{\nabla\mathcal{L}(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{D}_{k}^{t})^{\top}\nabla\mathcal{L}(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t})}{\nabla\mathcal{L}(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t})^{\top}\nabla\mathcal{L}(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t})}\nabla\mathcal{L}(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t})\bigg{)}.

Note that unlike in (5), this gradient correction step occurs purely on local weight wktsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡w_{k}^{t} and does not involve global weights 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}. The rationale for such modifications can be found in Section A.1.

   Remark 1.

Only one of (5) and (6) is executed in each local training iteration: gradients are updated based on the objective function in (2) only when (4) holds. Otherwise, as analytically demonstrated in Section 4.4, updating wktsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡w_{k}^{t} according to (6) multiple times allows the inner product ⟨∇ℒ​(wkt;𝒟kt),∇ℒ​(wkt;ℳkt)⟩∇ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑡∇ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscriptℳ𝑘𝑡\langle\nabla\mathcal{L}\left(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{D}_{k}^{t}\right),\nabla\mathcal{L}\left(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t}\right)\rangle (currently negative) to approach and eventually exceed zero.

In FedMeS, rather than fixing the regularization parameter λ𝜆\lambda in (2), we propose a novel loss-based approach for dynamically adjusting λ𝜆\lambda, to better draw useful information from other clients through the global model to facilitate learning of local tasks. Specifically, we set the value of λ𝜆\lambda as:

λ=2⋅sigmoid​(1ℒ​(𝐰,𝒟kt)).𝜆⋅2sigmoid1ℒ𝐰superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑡\lambda=2\cdot\text{sigmoid}\left(\frac{1}{\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w},\mathcal{D}_{k}^{t})}\right). (7)

Intuitively, when ℒ​(𝐰,𝒟kt)ℒ𝐰superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑡\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w},\mathcal{D}_{k}^{t}) is relatively large, it means the global model 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} performs poorly on the current task of client k𝑘k, and the personalized model wktsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡w_{k}^{t} should deviate from the global model by decreasing λ𝜆\lambda. On the other hand, a small ℒ​(𝐰,𝒟kt)ℒ𝐰superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑡\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{w},\mathcal{D}_{k}^{t}) would encourage wktsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡w_{k}^{t} to approach the global model 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}, which corresponds to a lager λ𝜆\lambda. The sigmoid function here limits λ𝜆\lambda within [0,2]02[0,2], following the result from [16].

4.3 Inference Process of FedMeS

As shown in Fig. 2, FedMeS also utilizes local memory to enhance inference performance. Specifically, to perform inference process after learning task t𝑡t, client k𝑘k first generates a set of representation-label pairs (R-L pairs) from the current local memory as {(Pwkt​(𝐦ki),y𝐦ki):(𝐦ki,y𝐦ki)∈ℳkt}conditional-setsubscript𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐦𝑘𝑖subscript𝑦superscriptsubscript𝐦𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐦𝑘𝑖subscript𝑦superscriptsubscript𝐦𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscriptℳ𝑘𝑡\left\{\left(P_{w_{k}^{t}}\left({\bf m}_{k}^{i}\right),y_{{\bf m}_{k}^{i}}\right):\left({\bf m}_{k}^{i},y_{{\bf m}_{k}^{i}}\right)\in\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t}\right\}, where 𝐦ki,i=1,…,|ℳkt|formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝐦𝑘𝑖𝑖1…superscriptsubscriptℳ𝑘𝑡{\bf m}_{k}^{i},i=1,\ldots,|{\cal M}_{k}^{t}|, is the input of the i𝑖i-th sample in ℳktsuperscriptsubscriptℳ𝑘𝑡{\cal M}_{k}^{t}, and y𝐦kisubscript𝑦superscriptsubscript𝐦𝑘𝑖y_{{\bf m}_{k}^{i}} is its label. Here d​i​s​t​(⋅,⋅)𝑑𝑖𝑠𝑡⋅⋅dist(\cdot,\cdot) could be any distance metric, and in FedMeS the Euclidean distance is used. Denote bwkt​(𝐱)subscript𝑏superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡𝐱b_{w_{k}^{t}}({\bf x}) as the local estimate of the conditional probability 𝒫ℳkt​(y|𝐱)subscript𝒫superscriptsubscriptℳ𝑘𝑡conditional𝑦𝐱\mathcal{P}_{\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t}}(y|\mathbf{x}), where 𝒫ℳktsubscript𝒫superscriptsubscriptℳ𝑘𝑡\mathcal{P}_{\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t}} is the probability distribution of ℳktsuperscriptsubscriptℳ𝑘𝑡\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t}. Then the K𝐾K nearest neighbours found in 𝒦(K)​(𝐱)superscript𝒦𝐾𝐱\mathcal{K}^{(K)}(\mathbf{x}) are used to compute [bwkt​(𝐱)]ysubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑏superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡𝐱𝑦[b_{w_{k}^{t}}(\mathbf{x})]_{y} with a Gaussian kernel:

[bwkt​(𝐱)]y∝∑j=1K𝟏y=y𝐦kj×exp⁡{−d​i​s​t​(Pwkt​(𝐱),Pwkt​(𝐦kj))}.proportional-tosubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑏superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡𝐱𝑦superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐾subscript1𝑦subscript𝑦superscriptsubscript𝐦𝑘𝑗𝑑𝑖𝑠𝑡subscript𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡𝐱subscript𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐦𝑘𝑗[b_{w_{k}^{t}}(\mathbf{x})]_{y}\!\propto\!\!\sum_{j=1}^{K}\mathbf{1}_{y=y_{{\bf m}_{k}^{j}}}{\!\times\!}\exp\{-dist(P_{w_{k}^{t}}\!(\mathbf{x}),P_{w_{k}^{t}}\!({\bf m}_{k}^{j}))\}. (9)

Finally, the FedMeS prediction result of 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} on client k𝑘k is obtain by a convex combination of outputs from local personalized model and KNN inference:

FedMeSk​(𝐱)=θk⋅bwkt​(𝐱)+(1−θk)​hwkt​(𝐱).subscriptFedMeS𝑘𝐱⋅subscript𝜃𝑘subscript𝑏superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡𝐱1subscript𝜃𝑘subscriptℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡𝐱\mathrm{FedMeS}_{k}(\mathbf{x})=\theta_{k}\cdot b_{w_{k}^{t}}(\mathbf{x})+(1-\theta_{k})h_{w_{k}^{t}}(\mathbf{x}). (10)

Here hwktsubscriptℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡h_{w_{k}^{t}} is the personalized local model parameterized by wktsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡w_{k}^{t}, and θk∈(0,1)subscript𝜃𝑘01\theta_{k}\in(0,1) is a combining parameter which can be tuned through local validation or cross-validation.

   Remark 2.

As proved in [33], augmenting the model inference with a memorization mechanism (KNN in this case) helps to improve the performance. In [13], local memorization through KNN has been applied to improve the accuracies of local models in personalized FL, for a single task. FedMeS extends the application of this technique on memorization over an arbitrary sequence of tasks, via utilizing a subset of samples from each task. Also, this inference enhancement of FedMeS comes for free, as this memory is readily available from the preceeding training process.

   Remark 3.

Another major advantage of FedMeS is that it is task-oblivious. That is, the same inference process is applied for all test samples, and no prior knowledge is needed about which task the sample belongs to. This also reflects the strong robustness of FedMeS: regardless of the original task, a good inference performance is always guaranteed by a unified FedMeS inference process. This is, however, not the case for other task-incremental learning CL methods like in [34].

4.4 Convergence Analysis

We analyze the convergence performance of FedMeS in Theorem 13 and 2, whose detailed proofs are given in Section A.2 and Section A.3 respectively.

We first make some assumptions to facilitate the analysis. For each global round r𝑟r of FedMeS to solve task t𝑡t, we denote wk(r),𝐰(r)superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑟superscript𝐰𝑟w_{k}^{(r)},\mathbf{w}^{(r)} respectively as the value of wktsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡w_{k}^{t} and 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} at round r𝑟r.

   Assumption 1.

The loss function ℒ​(wk)ℒsubscript𝑤𝑘\mathcal{L}(w_{k}) is c𝑐c-strongly convex and L𝐿L-smooth for k=1,…,n𝑘1…𝑛k=1,...,n. The expectation of stochastic gradients of the loss function ℒ​(wk(r))ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑟\mathcal{L}(w_{k}^{(r)}) on 𝒟ktsuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑡\mathcal{D}_{k}^{t} is uniformly bounded at all clients and all iterations, i.e.: 𝔼​[‖∇ℒ​(wk(r);ξkr)‖2]≤σ2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑟superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑟2superscript𝜎2\mathbb{E}[\|\nabla\mathcal{L}\left(w_{k}^{(r)};\xi_{k}^{r}\right)\|^{2}]\leq\sigma^{2}, where ξkrsuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑟\xi_{k}^{r} is the mini-batch data sampled from 𝒟ktsuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑡\mathcal{D}_{k}^{t} in round r𝑟r. The global model converges with rate g​(r)𝑔𝑟g(r), i.e., there exists g​(r)𝑔𝑟g(r) such that limr→∞​g​(r)=0subscriptlim→𝑟𝑔𝑟0\text{lim}_{r\rightarrow\infty}g(r)=0, 𝔼​[‖𝐰(r)−𝐰∗‖2]≤g​(r)𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscript𝐰𝑟superscript𝐰2𝑔𝑟\mathbb{E}[\|\mathbf{w}^{(r)}-\mathbf{w}^{*}\|^{2}]\leq g(r).

When (4) is not satisfied, FedMeS executes (6) to perform gradient correction.    Theorem 1.

(13)

Theorem 13 shows that, executing the gradient correction step iteratively ensures that ℒ​(wkt;ℳkt)ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscriptℳ𝑘𝑡\mathcal{L}(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t}) converges to its local optimum.    Theorem 2.

Under Assumption 1, and the condition that the constraint (4) is satisfied, there exists a constant C𝐶C such that for λ∈ℝ𝜆ℝ\lambda\in\mathbb{R}, wkrsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑟w_{k}^{r} converges to wk∗:=arg⁡minwktGk​(wkt;𝐰∗)assignsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡subscript𝐺𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscript𝐰w_{k}^{*}:=\mathop{\arg\min}_{w_{k}^{t}}G_{k}\left(w_{k}^{t};\mathbf{w}^{*}\right) with rate C​g​(r)𝐶𝑔𝑟Cg(r).

By Theorem 2, the local model wktsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡w_{k}^{t} would always converge to its optimum with a multiplicative gap from the rate of global convergence process.

5 Experiments

5.1 Setup

Datasets and models. We select five commonly used public datasets: CIFAR-100 [35], EMINIST [36], CORe50 [37], MiniImageNet-100 [38] and TinyImageNet-200. For the purpose of PFCL evaluation, we split these datasets into multiple tasks forming four cross-class datasets: Split CIFAR-100: CIFAR-100 consists of 100 classes, we split them into 10 tasks with 10 classes each. Split EMINIST: We utilize 60 of the 62 categories in the original dataset, and split them into 10 tasks with 6 classes each. A total of 120,000 imagines are used. Split CORe50: CORe50 is specifically designed for assessing continual learning techniques and has 50 objects collected in 11 different sessions. We naturally split it into 11 tasks with 50 classes each. Split MiniImageNet: MiniImageNet-100 is commonly used in few-shot learning benchmarks, which consists of 50,000 data points and 10,000 testing points from 100 classes. We split this dataset into 10 tasks with 10 classes each.

Besides, we also design cross-domain datasets to evaluate the cross domain performance for FedMeS. Fusion Tasks-40: This benchmark combines 200,000 images from three distinct datasets: CIFAR-100, MiniImageNet-100, and TinyImageNet-200, with a total of 400 classes. These classes are then divided into 40 non-IID tasks, with each task comprising 10 disjoint classes.

We use 6-layer CNNs for the Split CIFAR-100 and Split CORe50, 2-layer CNNs for the Split EMINIST, and ResNet-18 for Split MiniImageNet and Fusion Tasks-40. For the task and dataset distributions, each client is assigned a unique task sequence, in which a subset of 2-5 classes are randomly selected for each task, with the goal of ensuring data heterogeneity.

Metrics. We consider the following performance metrics.

∙∙\bullet Average Accuracy: We consider four different average accuracies. We define the averaged accuracy of client k𝑘k among all learned t𝑡t tasks after the training of task t𝑡t: Ak,t=1t​∑i=1tat,iksubscript𝐴𝑘𝑡1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑡𝑖𝑘A_{k,t}=\frac{1}{t}{\textstyle\sum_{i=1}^{t}}a_{t,i}^{k} as accuracy of client k𝑘k at task t𝑡t, where at,iksuperscriptsubscript𝑎𝑡𝑖𝑘a_{t,i}^{k} (i<t𝑖𝑡i<t) is the test accuracy of task i𝑖i after the training of task t𝑡t in client k𝑘k; averaged accuracy of client k𝑘k after training all T𝑇T tasks A​c​c​_​C​l​i​e​n​tk=1T​∑i=1TAk,i𝐴𝑐𝑐_𝐶𝑙𝑖𝑒𝑛subscript𝑡𝑘1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑇subscript𝐴𝑘𝑖Acc\_Client_{k}=\frac{1}{T}{\textstyle\sum_{i=1}^{T}}A_{k,i}; average accuracy among all n𝑛n clients at t𝑡t-th task: A​c​c​_​T​a​s​kt=1n​∑j=1nAj,t𝐴𝑐𝑐_𝑇𝑎𝑠subscript𝑘𝑡1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑛subscript𝐴𝑗𝑡Acc\_Task_{t}=\frac{1}{n}{\textstyle\sum_{j=1}^{n}}A_{j,t}; average accuracy among all n𝑛n clients in all learned T𝑇T tasks after completing the training process of all tasks: A​c​c​_​A​L​L=1n​1T​∑j=1n∑i=1TAj,t𝐴𝑐𝑐_𝐴𝐿𝐿1𝑛1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑇subscript𝐴𝑗𝑡Acc\_ALL=\frac{1}{n}\frac{1}{T}{\textstyle\sum_{j=1}^{n}}{\textstyle\sum_{i=1}^{T}}A_{j,t}.

∙∙\bullet Forgetting rate: The forgetting rate Ftksuperscriptsubscript𝐹𝑡𝑘F_{t}^{k} of client k𝑘k at t𝑡t-th task is defined as Ftk=1t−1​∑i=1t−1maxj∈{1,…,t−1}⁡(aj,ik−at,ik)superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑡𝑘1𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑡1subscript𝑗1…𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑗𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑡𝑖𝑘F_{t}^{k}=\frac{1}{t-1}{\textstyle\sum_{i=1}^{t-1}}\max_{j\in\{1,\dots,t-1\}}(a_{j,i}^{k}-a_{t,i}^{k}), which measures the maximum accuracy loss when incorporating new tasks. Forgetting rate indicates the capability of resisting catastrophic forgetting.

Baselines. We compare our proposed FedMeS with other personalized FL and FCL baselines. ∙∙\bullet FedAvg: A classical FL method which the server aggregates the models for all clients according to a weighted averaging of model parameters in each clients.

∙∙\bullet Ditto: A simple personalized FL method that utilizes a regularization term addressing the accuracy, robustness and fairness in FL while optimizing communication efficiency.

∙∙\bullet FedRep: A personalized FL method that learns a divided model with global representation and personalized heads. Only the global representation is communicated between the server and clients, while each client adapts to its personalized head locally.

∙∙\bullet FedAGEM: An FCL method that combines the conventional A-GEM method with FedAvg.

∙∙\bullet FedWeIT: State-of-the-art FCL approach based on parameter isolation, which uses masks to divide the model parameter into base and task-adaptive parameters. The server averages the base parameters and broadcasts the task-adaptive parameters to all clients. Each client then trains all the task-adaptive parameters with the new task’s weights parameters based on a regularized objective.

Descriptions of Hyperparameters. For all the experiment, Adam optimizer is applied with adaptive learning rate which decay per round. Local sample batch size is 40. The participation rate(fraction) for the clients is set to 1. For Split CIFAR-100, Split EMINIST, Split CORe50 and Split MiniImageNet, 10 local epochs is performed in each communication round. And in Fusion Tasks-40, 5 local epochs is performed in each communication round. For each task a total of 10 communication rounds is performed. The regularization parameter λ𝜆\lambda in Ditto is set to 0.1. Number of memory samples in FedAGEM and proposed FedMeS is set to 150. The θksubscript𝜃𝑘\theta_{k} in FedMeS is set to 0.5, and the number of nearest neighbours is set to 9.

All the experiments are conducted using PyTorch version 1.9 on a single machine equipped with two Intel Xeon 6226R CPUs, 384GB of memory, and four NVIDIA 3090 GPUs. Each experiment is repeated for 5 times. The averages and standard deviations of the above metrics are reported.

5.2 Cross-class Performance

We observe in Table 1 that, for all cross-class datasets and number of clients, FedMeS outperforms all baselines in terms of average accuracy and forgetting rate. Notably, when compared to the state-of-the-art baseline FedWeIT, FedMeS achieves a performance boost of up to 102%percent102102\% in Split MiniImageNet. Additionally, FedMeS consistently outperforms FedWeIT in terms of forgetting rate, achieving a reduction of 4 to 6 times on the Split CORe50 dataset. Here FedWeIT experiences a significant decline in performance when applied to the Split MiniImageNet with ResNet-18. This is primarily due to its requirement of modifying the model structure to decompose the model parameters individually. Specifically, the downsample layers in ResNet-18 contain a relatively small number of essential parameters, and decomposing these layers negatively impacted the model’s accuracy. Additionally, the local inference process used in FedMeS has shown promising improvements (5%percent\% to 10%percent\% better performance in A​c​c​_​A​L​L𝐴𝑐𝑐_𝐴𝐿𝐿Acc\_ALL(Acc)), particularly when compared to FedMeS (noLIP).

Catastrophic forgetting. As shown in Fig. 3, FedMeS consistently achieves the highest accuracy and lowest forgetting rate, for all tasks under all settings. Catastrophic forgetting causes serious limitation for FedAvg and Ditto, as they do not incorporate previous task information in training. FedRep exhibits certain robustness against heterogeneity over clients. But without a designed mechanism to address catastrophic forgetting, it still subjects to gradual decay in average accuracy as new tasks arrive. The isolation method of FedWeIT to obtain adaptive weights on the clients cannot well maintain the knowledge from the previous tasks, resulting in a lower accuracy than FedMeS.

Client drift. As shown in Fig. 4, in all settings, FedMeS achieves the highest accuracy over all clients, thanks to its reliable personalization mechanism and local inference process. Also, FedMeS has the narrowest shaded area over all clients, indicating its ability to maintain consistent performance across all tasks for all clients. FedAGEM and FedWeIT fail to effectively address data heterogeneity, resulting in inferior model performance. FedWeIT relies on the stored knowledge of all tasks at the server, which may dilute the impact of individual tasks of each client.

Fig. 5 to Fig. 6 present the A​c​c​_​T​a​s​k𝐴𝑐𝑐_𝑇𝑎𝑠𝑘Acc\_Task and A​c​c​_​C​l​i​e​n​t𝐴𝑐𝑐_𝐶𝑙𝑖𝑒𝑛𝑡Acc\_Client for the Split EMINIST and Split CORe50 datasets. For every experiments FedMeS achieves highest A​c​c​_​T​a​s​k𝐴𝑐𝑐_𝑇𝑎𝑠𝑘Acc\_Task and lowest forgetting rate, and for each client FedMeS achieves the best A​c​c​_​C​l​i​e​n​t𝐴𝑐𝑐_𝐶𝑙𝑖𝑒𝑛𝑡Acc\_Client.

5.3 Cross-domain Performance

Fig. 7 shows the averaged test accuracy of each client across all tasks in the Fusion Tasks-40 dataset. The results indicate that the proposed FedMeS method outperforms the FedWeIT method, with higher average accuracy and lower forgetting rate among all clients and tasks. The poor performance of certain clients has a significant impact on other clients, and the isolation method employed by FedWeIT to mitigate catastrophic forgetting proves to be ineffective in the considered dataset with a large number of tasks. In contrast, the proposed FedMeS method achieves consistent performance across all tasks and clients, demonstrating its capability in scaling to large PFCL systems.

Effect of memory size. We observe in Fig. 8 (a) that FedMeS is memory efficient, such that with storing as small as 30 data samples in local memory, an accuracy of 48%percent4848\% can be achieved. As the memory size increases, the accuracy gradually improves, and persists around 55%percent5555\% after the memory size reaches 150 data samples. For heterogeneous memory sizes across different clients is shown in Fig. 9. As an instance, ‘Here10-50’ denotes that every two clients are allocated memory samples spanning from 10 to 50, with a step of 10 samples, ‘Fix50’ denotes a consistent allocation of 50 memory samples per client. Since each client is assigned with a unique task sequence, the memory sizes for each task is also heterogeneous. The A​c​c​_​T​a​s​k𝐴𝑐𝑐_𝑇𝑎𝑠𝑘Acc\_Task boxplot reveals that FedMeS exhibits a broader accuracy range for each task under heterogeneous memory settings as opposed to fixed ones. Corroborating with Fig. 8, shown that performance in heterogeneous memory conditions is primarily influenced by the minimal memory sample size in each configuration. In terms of A​c​c​_​A​L​L𝐴𝑐𝑐_𝐴𝐿𝐿Acc\_ALL, it consistently surpasses other baselines from results in Table 1, further showing the robustness of FedMeS under various conditions.

Communication and computation efficiency. We compare the communication and computation efficiency between FedMeS and FedWeIT in wall clock time, imposing a communication bandwidth limit of 40Mbps between the server and clients. The results, depicted in Fig. 8 (b), show that for all considered experiment settings, FedMeS outperforms FedWeIT by achieving higher accuracy using shorter execution time. This advantage becomes particularly prominent when experimenting with larger numbers of clients and tasks.

6 Conclusion

This paper has presented the challenges associated with catastrophic forgetting and client drift in PFCL and proposed the FedMeS framework as a solution to these issues. FedMeS levearges a small reference memory in the local training process to replay knowledge from previous tasks to alleviate forgetting; and the same memory is also used for the inference process by applying KNN-based Gaussian inference to further improve model personalization capability. We thoroughly analyzed the convergence behavior of FedMeS, and performed extensive experiments over various PFCL tasks. For all experiments, FedMeS uniformly outperforms existing techniques in terms of prediction accuracy and forgetting rate.

Appendix

Appendix A Detailed Theoretical Analysis

In this section, we give theoretical analysis on how our algorithm uses local memories and provide convergence proof of the local training process.

A.1 Reasoning of Local Continual Learning

In this section, we provide inference on how (2) can utilize memories of past tasks and how the update rule in (5) and (6) can solve the optimization problem.

To conduct continual learning in the centralized setting, [24] raises the concept of episodic memory, where for every task t𝑡t, a central memory ℳtsubscriptℳ𝑡\mathcal{M}_{t} is utilized to store examples sampled from task t𝑡t. Denote l​(hw;𝒟)𝑙subscriptℎ𝑤𝒟l(h_{w};\mathcal{D}) as the loss function hypothesis hwsubscriptℎ𝑤h_{w} on dataset 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}, where hwsubscriptℎ𝑤h_{w} is the hypothesis with parameter w𝑤w, and to avoid catastrophic forgetting, the authors raises that the loss of current model on previous tasks j=1,…,t−1𝑗1…𝑡1j=1,...,t-1, i.e. l​(hw;ℳj)𝑙subscriptℎ𝑤subscriptℳ𝑗l(h_{w};\mathcal{M}_{j}) should not increase but decrease while minimizing loss on current task t𝑡t, i.e. l​(hw;𝒟t)𝑙subscriptℎ𝑤superscript𝒟𝑡l(h_{w};\mathcal{D}^{t}), where 𝒟tsuperscript𝒟𝑡\mathcal{D}^{t} is task t𝑡t’s dataset. However, this method requires computing on all memory block ℳjsubscriptℳ𝑗\mathcal{M}_{j} for every j<t𝑗𝑡j<t, which is computationally expensive.

Authors of [25], simplify the above decreasing constraint of losses on previous tasks into into an inequality constraint: by every training step the average memory loss over the previous tasks does not increase. Formally speaking, while learning task t𝑡t, the objective is,

minimizewsubscriptminimize𝑤\displaystyle\text{minimize}_{w} l​(hwt;𝒟t)𝑙superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑤𝑡superscript𝒟𝑡\displaystyle l(h_{w}^{t};\mathcal{D}^{t}) (14)
   s.t. l​(hwt;ℳt)≤l​(hwt−1;ℳt)𝑙subscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑡𝑤superscriptℳ𝑡𝑙superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑤𝑡1superscriptℳ𝑡\displaystyle l(h^{t}_{w};\mathcal{M}^{t})\leq l(h_{w}^{t-1};\mathcal{M}^{t})
   where ℳt=∪j<tℳjsuperscriptℳ𝑡subscript𝑗𝑡subscriptℳ𝑗\displaystyle\mathcal{M}^{t}=\cup_{j<t}\mathcal{M}_{j}

where 𝒟tsuperscript𝒟𝑡\mathcal{D}^{t} is dataset of current task t𝑡t and hwtsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑤𝑡h_{w}^{t} is the predictor state at the end of learning of task t𝑡t. In the federated setting, we focus on the single client k𝑘k for task t𝑡t, and the objective changes into,

minwktℒ​(wkt;𝒟kt)s.t.ℒ​(wkt;ℳkt)≤ℒ​(wkt−1;ℳkt)subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑡s.t.ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscriptℳ𝑘𝑡ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡1superscriptsubscriptℳ𝑘𝑡\min_{w_{k}^{t}}\quad\mathcal{L}\left(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{D}_{k}^{t}\right)\quad\text{s.t.}\quad\mathcal{L}\left(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t}\right)\leq\mathcal{L}\left(w_{k}^{t-1};\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t}\right) (15)

where wktsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡w_{k}^{t}, 𝒟ktsuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑡\mathcal{D}_{k}^{t}, ℳktsuperscriptsubscriptℳ𝑘𝑡\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t} are respectively the model parameters, the dataset and the memory block of task t𝑡t on client k𝑘k, as defined in Chapter 3 and 4.1.

Moreover, [24] raises that it is unnecessary to store all the old predictors hwj,j<tsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑤𝑗𝑗𝑡h_{w}^{j},j<t under the circumstance that the loss on the previous memories does not increase after each parameter update g𝑔g. As the memorized examples being representative of past tasks, the increases of previous memory could be diagnosed by computing the angle between the previous loss gradient vector and the current proposed update. Therefore, (14) could be restated as:

⟨g,gmem⟩:=⟨∂l​(hwt;𝒟t)∂w,∂l​(hwt;ℳt)∂w⟩≥0assign𝑔subscript𝑔mem𝑙superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑤𝑡superscript𝒟𝑡𝑤𝑙superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑤𝑡superscriptℳ𝑡𝑤0\left\langle g,g_{\operatorname{mem}}\right\rangle:=\left\langle\frac{\partial l(h_{w}^{t};\mathcal{D}^{t})}{\partial w},\frac{\partial l(h_{w}^{t};\mathcal{M}^{t})}{\partial w}\right\rangle\geq 0 (16)

where gmemsubscript𝑔memg_{\operatorname{mem}} is the gradient computed using a batch randomly sampled from the memory, i.e. (𝐱mem,ymem)∼ℳsimilar-tosubscript𝐱memsubscript𝑦memℳ(\mathbf{x}_{\operatorname{mem}},y_{\operatorname{mem}})\sim\mathcal{M}. If the constraint in (16) is satisfied, the current proposed update g𝑔g would decrease the loss on previous memories. However, if violation occurs, we could propose to project the proposed gradient g𝑔g to the closet gradient g~~𝑔\tilde{g} (in squared l2subscript𝑙2l_{2} norm) satisfying (16). It can be rephrased as:

minimizeg~12​‖g−g~‖22s.t.g~⊤​gmem≥0subscriptminimize~𝑔12superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑔~𝑔22s.t.superscript~𝑔topsubscript𝑔mem0\text{minimize}_{\tilde{g}}\quad\frac{1}{2}\|g-\tilde{g}\|_{2}^{2}\quad\text{s.t.}\quad\tilde{g}^{\top}g_{\operatorname{mem}}\geq 0 (17)

In [25], the optimization problem in (17) is solved as below. With z𝑧z replacing g~~𝑔\tilde{g} and discard the term g⊤​gsuperscript𝑔top𝑔g^{\top}g, (17) could be rewritten as below:

minimizez12​z⊤​z−g⊤​zs.t.−z⊤​gmem≤0subscriptminimize𝑧12superscript𝑧top𝑧superscript𝑔top𝑧s.t.superscript𝑧topsubscript𝑔mem0\text{minimize}_{z}\quad\frac{1}{2}z^{\top}z-g^{\top}z\quad\text{s.t.}\quad-z^{\top}g_{\operatorname{mem}}\leq 0 (18)

Note that the sign of inequality constraint is changed for Lagrangian dual problem. By adding the Lagrangian multiplier λ𝜆\lambda, the Lagrangian of (18) is:

ℒ​(z,λ)=12​z⊤​z−g⊤​z−λ​z⊤​gmemℒ𝑧𝜆12superscript𝑧top𝑧superscript𝑔top𝑧𝜆superscript𝑧topsubscript𝑔mem\mathcal{L}(z,\lambda)=\frac{1}{2}z^{\top}z-g^{\top}z-\lambda z^{\top}g_{\operatorname{mem}} (19)

The dual problem of (19) is:

Θ​(λ)=m​i​nz​ℒ​(z,λ)Θ𝜆𝑚𝑖subscript𝑛𝑧ℒ𝑧𝜆\Theta(\lambda)=min_{z}\mathcal{L}(z,\lambda) (20)

The optimal value z∗superscript𝑧z^{*} for the primal problem could be yielded by setting ∇zL​(z,λ)=0subscript∇𝑧𝐿𝑧𝜆0\nabla_{z}L(z,\lambda)=0, and we have:

z∗=g+λ​gmemsuperscript𝑧𝑔𝜆subscript𝑔memz^{*}=g+\lambda g_{\operatorname{mem}} (21)

Putting the value of z∗superscript𝑧z^{*} back to dual problem (20), and the dual could be rewritten as:

Θ​(λ)Θ𝜆\displaystyle\Theta(\lambda) =12​(g+λ​gmem)⊤(g+λ​gmem)−absenttop12𝑔𝜆subscript𝑔memlimit-from𝑔𝜆subscript𝑔mem\displaystyle=\frac{1}{2}(g+\lambda g_{\operatorname{mem}})\top(g+\lambda g_{\operatorname{mem}})- (22)
g⊤​(g+λ​gmem)−λ​(g+λ​gmem)⊤​gmemsuperscript𝑔top𝑔𝜆subscript𝑔mem𝜆superscript𝑔𝜆subscript𝑔memtopsubscript𝑔mem\displaystyle\quad\quad\quad\ g^{\top}(g+\lambda g_{\operatorname{mem}})-\lambda(g+\lambda g_{\operatorname{mem}})^{\top}g_{\operatorname{mem}}

gT​g−λ​g⊤​gmem−λ​g⊤​gmem−λ2​gmem⊤​gmemsuperscript𝑔𝑇𝑔𝜆superscript𝑔topsubscript𝑔mem𝜆superscript𝑔topsubscript𝑔memsuperscript𝜆2subscriptsuperscript𝑔topmemsubscript𝑔mem\displaystyle\quad\quad\quad g^{T}g-\lambda g^{\top}g_{\operatorname{mem}}-\lambda g^{\top}g_{\operatorname{mem}}-\lambda^{2}g^{\top}_{\operatorname{mem}}g_{\operatorname{mem}}

The solution λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*} is given by ∇λΘ​(λ)=0subscript∇𝜆Θ𝜆0\nabla_{\lambda}\Theta(\lambda)=0, i.e. gmem⊤​gmem​λ+g⊤​gmem=0subscriptsuperscript𝑔topmemsubscript𝑔mem𝜆superscript𝑔topsubscript𝑔mem0g^{\top}_{\operatorname{mem}}g_{\operatorname{mem}}\lambda+g^{\top}g_{\operatorname{mem}}=0. As a result,

λ∗=−g⊤​gmemgmem⊤​gmemsuperscript𝜆superscript𝑔topsubscript𝑔memsubscriptsuperscript𝑔topmemsubscript𝑔mem\displaystyle\lambda^{*}=-\frac{g^{\top}g_{\operatorname{mem}}}{g^{\top}_{\operatorname{mem}}g_{\operatorname{mem}}} (23)

Putting back λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*} in (21), the update rule would be:

z∗=g−g⊤​gmemgmem⊤​gmem​gmem=g~superscript𝑧𝑔superscript𝑔topsubscript𝑔memsubscriptsuperscript𝑔topmemsubscript𝑔memsubscript𝑔mem~𝑔\displaystyle z^{*}=g-\frac{g^{\top}g_{\operatorname{mem}}}{g^{\top}_{\operatorname{mem}}g_{\operatorname{mem}}}g_{\operatorname{mem}}=\tilde{g} (24)

Next, we go back to the definition of gradient g𝑔g and gmemsubscript𝑔memg_{\operatorname{mem}}. g𝑔g is the proposed gradient update on the current task, and in the federated setting, it refers to the gradient of the personalized parameter wktsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡w_{k}^{t} on the client k𝑘k’s dataset of task t𝑡t, i.e. 𝒟ktsuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑡\mathcal{D}_{k}^{t}. gmemsubscript𝑔memg_{\operatorname{mem}} is the gradient from the previous tasks computed from a random subset of the memory, and in the federated setting, it refers to the gradient of the personalized parameter wktsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡w_{k}^{t} on the client k𝑘k’s local memory till task t𝑡t, i.e. ℳktsuperscriptsubscriptℳ𝑘𝑡\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t}. Formally we can define g𝑔g and gm​e​msubscript𝑔𝑚𝑒𝑚g_{m}em in PFCL problem as,

g:=assign𝑔absent\displaystyle g:= ∇ℒ​(wkt;𝒟kt)∇ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑡\displaystyle\nabla\mathcal{L}(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{D}_{k}^{t}) (25)
gmem:=assignsubscript𝑔memabsent\displaystyle g_{\operatorname{mem}}:= ∇ℒ​(wkt;ℳkt)∇ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscriptℳ𝑘𝑡\displaystyle\nabla\mathcal{L}(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t})

Based on the above analysis, in a federated setting, the constraint (16) turns into (4) when we want to minimize wktsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡w_{k}^{t} in (2) on client k𝑘k for current task t𝑡t,

∙∙\bullet If ⟨∇ℒ​(wkt;𝒟kt),∇ℒ​(wkt;ℳkt)⟩≥0∇ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑡∇ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscriptℳ𝑘𝑡0\left\langle\nabla\mathcal{L}(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{D}_{k}^{t}),\nabla\mathcal{L}(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t})\right\rangle\geq 0, meaning that the angle of proposed gradient g𝑔g and gradient on the memory gmem<90∘subscript𝑔memsuperscript90g_{\operatorname{mem}}<90^{\circ}, so the update would not make for forgetting on the past examples. We could just calculate ∇ℒ​(wk;Dkt)∇ℒsubscript𝑤𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑘𝑡\nabla\mathcal{L}(w_{k};D_{k}^{t}) for this update, i.e.:

wkt←wkt−η1​∇ℒ​(wkt;𝒟kt)←superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡subscript𝜂1∇ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑡w_{k}^{t}\leftarrow w_{k}^{t}-\eta_{1}\nabla\mathcal{L}(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{D}_{k}^{t}) (26)

Under this circumstance, the local update ensures the optimization both on the current task and local memories. As a result, the communication to the central server would not impede the local memories, and the regularization term λ𝜆\lambda could be added to interpolate the global model and the local model, which turns into (5).

∙∙\bullet Else, if ⟨∇ℒ​(wkt;𝒟kt),∇ℒ​(wkt;ℳkt)⟩<0∇ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑡∇ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscriptℳ𝑘𝑡0\left\langle\nabla\mathcal{L}(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{D}_{k}^{t}),\nabla\mathcal{L}(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t})\right\rangle<0, meaning that the angle of proposed gradient g𝑔g and gradient on the memory gmem≥90∘subscript𝑔memsuperscript90g_{\operatorname{mem}}\geq 90^{\circ}, so we should use the projected gradient g~~𝑔\tilde{g} for update, under which circumstance we have:

g~~𝑔\displaystyle\tilde{g} =g−g⊤​gmemgmem⊤​gmem​gmemabsent𝑔superscript𝑔topsubscript𝑔memsubscriptsuperscript𝑔topmemsubscript𝑔memsubscript𝑔mem\displaystyle=g-\frac{g^{\top}g_{\operatorname{mem}}}{g^{\top}_{\operatorname{mem}}g_{\operatorname{mem}}}g_{\operatorname{mem}} (27)
=∇ℒ​(wkt;𝒟kt)−absentlimit-from∇ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑡\displaystyle=\nabla\mathcal{L}(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{D}_{k}^{t})-

which is exactly how the iteration takes place in (6).

Above is how the clients use local memory data to strengthen the personalized continual learning in PFCL.

Discussions. Theorem 13 shows that ℒ​(wkt;ℳkt)ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscriptℳ𝑘𝑡\mathcal{L}(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t}) can always converge to ℒ∗​(ℳkt)superscriptℒsuperscriptsubscriptℳ𝑘𝑡\mathcal{L}^{*}(\mathcal{M}_{k}^{t}) with the update rule of (6). Thus, whenever the current parameter wktsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡w_{k}^{t} violates the inequality limit (4) when running the update rule of (5), by applying (6) repeatedly the loss on memory ℒ​(wkt;ℳk)ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡subscriptℳ𝑘\mathcal{L}(w_{k}^{t};\mathcal{M}_{k}) would always converge to the optimal ℒ∗​(ℳk)superscriptℒsubscriptℳ𝑘\mathcal{L}^{*}(\mathcal{M}_{k}). As ℒ​(wk(t−1);ℳk)ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑡1subscriptℳ𝑘\mathcal{L}(w_{k}^{(t-1)};\mathcal{M}_{k}) can be viewed as a constant when solving task t𝑡t, under the assurance of the convergence analysis, updating rule (6) can ensure that current loss on ℳksubscriptℳ𝑘\mathcal{M}_{k} would gradually get smaller and finally, at a certain step, satisfy the constraint of (3), and the algorithm goes on.
